messages.text:
<@U66SGEWAC> when using JSServe and WGLMakie on a server that a single client listens to, what is better (in terms of dropped packages / speed / lag / etc):
1. have one loop that updates one observable?
2. have one loop that updates two observables?
3. have two loops that update one observable each with similar iteration times?
In option #1, the observable will contain the two observables I'm actually interested in.

Just to take this one step further: What's "better", an observable that contains an image that updates with some FPS, or `n x m` observables that update a single pixel iff it significantly changed since the last update...?

elements.text: when using JSServe and WGLMakie on a server that a single client listens to, what is better (in terms of dropped packages / speed / lag / etc):
have one loop that updates one observable?
have one loop that updates two observables?
have two loops that update one observable each with similar iteration times?

In option #1, the observable will contain the two observables I'm actually interested in.

Just to take this one step further: What's "better", an observable that contains an image that updates with some FPS, or
n x m
observables that update a single pixel iff it significantly changed since the last update...?

messages.text: I've noticed that in the output of `export_standalone`, in `core.js` and `index.html`, there are a few web socket calls. They essentially just error when I open the file in my browser. What are they for exactly? Is it some sort of fallback in case the julia session is still active? Is it ok to just let them error, or is there a way to remove them?

export_standalone

core.js
and
index.html

messages.text:
Someone has shared with me a code like this:
```ax = layout[1, :] = LScene(scene)
o = AbstractPlotting.Point3f0(-25, y, 0)
w = AbstractPlotting.Point3f0(50, y, 50)
p = AbstractPlotting.FRect3D(o, w)
a = AbstractPlotting.RGBAf0(0,0,0,0)
c = AbstractPlotting.RGBAf0(0.2, 0.2, 0.8, 1.0)
img = AbstractPlotting.ImagePattern([c a; a c]);
AbstractPlotting.mesh!(ax, p; color = img);```
which produces true transparent planes. But now when I run it I get an error I was not getting before that reads:
```ERROR: MethodError: no method matching to_image(::Combined{AbstractPlotting.mesh,Tuple{GeometryBasics.Mesh{3,Float32,GeometryBasics.Ngon{3,Float32,3,GeometryBasics.PointMeta{3,Float32,Point{3,Float32},(:uv, :normals),Tuple{Vec{2,Float32},Vec{3,Float32}}}},FaceView{GeometryBasics.Ngon{3,Float32,3,GeometryBasics.PointMeta{3,Float32,Point{3,Float32},(:uv, :normals),Tuple{Vec{2,Float32},Vec{3,Float32}}}}}}}})
Closest candidates are:
  to_image(::AbstractPlotting.ImagePattern) at C:\Users\datse\.julia\packages\AbstractPlotting\40gRI\src\patterns.jl:35
  to_image(::AbstractPlotting.LinePattern) at C:\Users\datse\.julia\packages\AbstractPlotting\40gRI\src\patterns.jl:106```
and I'm not sure why it happens now but wasn't happening before. My versions are:
```(@v1.5) pkg> st AbstractPlotting GLMakie
Status `C:\Users\datse\.julia\environments\v1.5\Project.toml`
  [537997a7] AbstractPlotting v0.14.2
  [e9467ef8] GLMakie v0.1.19```
Should I open an issue?

messages.text:
I am trying to record videos of plots inside a Docker container. It's based on Ubuntu 20.04, I am using GLMakie v0.1.20, and I have plotting mostly working. I can plot and save those plots as images. However, I am running into a problem trying to record plots:
```ERROR: Screen not open!
Stacktrace:
 [1] error(::String) at ./error.jl:33
 [2] colorbuffer(::GLMakie.Screen, ::AbstractPlotting.ImageStorageFormat) at /root/.julia/packages/GLMakie/WsRKK/src/screen.jl:194
 [3] recordframe!(::VideoStream) at /root/.julia/packages/AbstractPlotting/40gRI/src/display.jl:471
 [4] Record(::LeukoPlots.var"#11#12"{Bool,LeukoPlots.ResultPlot}, ::Scene, ::StepRangeLen{Float64,Base.TwicePrecision{Float64},Base.TwicePrecision{Float64}}; framerate::Int64) at /root/.julia/packages/AbstractPlotting/40gRI/src/display.jl:631
 [5] #record#897 at /root/.julia/packages/AbstractPlotting/40gRI/src/display.jl:622 [inlined]
 [6] record_plot(::LeukoTypes.Result, ::Array{Array{ColorTypes.Gray{FixedPointNumbers.Normed{UInt8,8}},2},1}, ::String; desired_framerate::Int64, compression::Int64, resolution::Tuple{Int64,Int64}, yrange::Array{Int64,1}, zoomspan::Float64, showprogressbars::Bool, unset_video::Bool) at /root/.julia/packages/LeukoPlots/g7NCi/src/plotting.jl:172
 [7] record_plot(::LeukoTypes.Result, ::Array{Array{ColorTypes.Gray{FixedPointNumbers.Normed{UInt8,8}},2},1}, ::String) at /root/.julia/packages/LeukoPlots/g7NCi/src/plotting.jl:158
 [8] top-level scope at REPL[17]:1```
I am running Julia under `xvfb-run` in the container, so it has a display. <@U66SGEWAC> Have you ever run into this issue before with your headless plotting experiments? I have recording plots working fine in our EC2 instances, so I know this is possible. I can't remember what I did to create that environment though :cry:

messages.text: Hi there, I've made a Makie plot which allows me to scroll through grid view of a labeled data set intended for machine learning applications. The plot shows different data transformations along the columns, and different data points along the rows, and supports scrolling with up/down arrow keys. The image/gist shows how I can use it to plot the MNIST data set (<https://gist.github.com/jonalm/d88d7e65ea3945d9dcbaf206e546f69d>). I experience that the Makie plot suddenly crashes after some scrolling, but I've tried to make sure that I'm not allocating new memory when scrolling. How can I debug such crashes? Is there a convenient way to log what goes on with the plot Observables during the lifetime of the plot?

messages.text:
How to clear/reset/replace an axis? This code keeps the old axis overlaid with the new one.
```using GLMakie
scene, layout = layoutscene()
display(scene)

# create axis and plot:
layout[1, 1] = ax = LAxis(scene)
scatter!(ax, rand(10), rand(10))

# make a completely different plot at the same layout position:
layout[1, 1] = ax = LAxis(scene)
scatter!(ax, rand(10), rand(10))```

elements.text: How to clear/reset/replace an axis? This code keeps the old axis overlaid with the new one.

using GLMakie
scene, layout = layoutscene()
display(scene)

# create axis and plot:
layout[1, 1] = ax = LAxis(scene)
scatter!(ax, rand(10), rand(10))

# make a completely different plot at the same layout position:
layout[1, 1] = ax = LAxis(scene)
scatter!(ax, rand(10), rand(10))

messages.text:
```using DynamicalBilliards, InteractiveChaos, GLMakie

SV = SVector{2, Float32}
w = 0.4 # stump width
points_right = [
    SV(w, 0),
    SV(w, w),
    SV(2.0, w),
    SV(w, 1.5),
    SV(1.5, 1.5),
    SV(w, 2.25),
    SV(1.0, 2.25),
]
summit = SV(0.0, 3.0)
points_left = reverse!([SV(-p[1], p[2]) for p in points_right])
tree_points = [points_right..., summit, points_left...]

tree_billiard = billiard_vertices(tree_points)

ps = particlebeam(0.0, 0.1, π/4, 1, 0.01, nothing, Float32)

interactive_billiard(tree_billiard, ps; dt = 0.1)```

elements.text:
using DynamicalBilliards, InteractiveChaos, GLMakie

SV = SVector{2, Float32}
w = 0.4 # stump width
points_right = [
    SV(w, 0),
    SV(w, w),
    SV(2.0, w),
    SV(w, 1.5),
    SV(1.5, 1.5),
    SV(w, 2.25),
    SV(1.0, 2.25),
]
summit = SV(0.0, 3.0)
points_left = reverse!([SV(-p[1], p[2]) for p in points_right])
tree_points = [points_right..., summit, points_left...]

tree_billiard = billiard_vertices(tree_points)

ps = particlebeam(0.0, 0.1, π/4, 1, 0.01, nothing, Float32)

interactive_billiard(tree_billiard, ps; dt = 0.1)

messages.text:
Hi!  How does one adjust a colorbar to a given contourf?  I looked at the tutorials but it wasn’t very clear.

This is my script so far:
```scene,layout = layoutscene(resolution = (900, 850))
	
ax1 = layout[1,1] = LAxis(scene,title="ζ")
cf = contourf!(ax1,x/1e3,y/1e3,ζ'*1e3,levels=vcat(0,0.05,0.1,0.2,0.5,1:5))
xlims!(ax1,-100,100)
ylims!(ax1,-100,100)
ax1.xlabel = "x / km"
ax1.ylabel = "y / km"
rowsize!(layout,1,Aspect(1,1))
	
ax2 = layout[1,2] = LColorbar(scene,cf,width=30)```

elements.text:

messages.text:
A quick question about the behavior of 3D plots with Layouts. Depending on the order in which LText and LScene are created one gets different behavior.  For example, The following code
```using AbstractPlotting
using Makie
# MWE
## LScene then LText
scene, layout = layoutscene()
lscene = layout[2,1:4] = LScene(scene)
layout[1, 1:4] = LText(scene, "Expected", textsize = 50)
volume!(lscene, 0..1, 0..1, 0..1, zeros(3,3,3))
display(scene)
## LText then LScene
scene, layout = layoutscene()
layout[1, 1:4] = LText(scene, "Unexpected", textsize = 50)
lscene = layout[2,1:4] = LScene(scene)
volume!(lscene, 0..1, 0..1, 0..1, zeros(3,3,3))
display(scene)```
produces the following plots: (is this expected?)

elements.text: A quick question about the behavior of 3D plots with Layouts. Depending on the order in which LText and LScene are created one gets different behavior.  For example, The following code

using AbstractPlotting
using Makie
# MWE
## LScene then LText
scene, layout = layoutscene()
lscene = layout[2,1:4] = LScene(scene)
layout[1, 1:4] = LText(scene, "Expected", textsize = 50)
volume!(lscene, 0..1, 0..1, 0..1, zeros(3,3,3))
display(scene)
## LText then LScene
scene, layout = layoutscene()
layout[1, 1:4] = LText(scene, "Unexpected", textsize = 50)
lscene = layout[2,1:4] = LScene(scene)
volume!(lscene, 0..1, 0..1, 0..1, zeros(3,3,3))
display(scene)
produces the following plots: (is this expected?)

messages.text: I'd like to be able to have 2 `textslider`s depend on one another. For example one slider allows the user to specify x, and the other 1 - x. Whenever one is changed the other should change accordingly, and updates to either should be able to set some observable for use elsewhere, e.g. to change the translation of some element in the Scene. Can this be done?

messages.text: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-makie-update-figures-and-integrated-layouts/52800|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-makie-update-figures-and-integrated-layouts/52800>

attachments.title: [ANN] Makie Update: Figures And Integrated Layouts
attachments.text: Hey everybody, For the last months Simon and I have been working on streamlining the integration of MakieLayout in the Makie ecosystem. Now, with AbstractPlotting.jl v0.15, we finally have made some bigger changes to our default plotting pipeline to make the features of MakieLayout more easily accessible and reduce boilerplate by a lot. The biggest change is that where you had to write this before to use MakieLayout’s more powerful axis: scene, layout = layoutscene() ax = layout[1, 1] = LAxis...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: [ANN] Makie Update: Figures And Integrated Layouts

elements.text: https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-makie-update-figures-and-integrated-layouts/52800

messages.text:
When we plot a surface or heatmap with (x, y, z), x and y are vectors and z needs to be a matrix.
 I usually have z as a vector, and I convert it to a matrix with `Matrix` and `sparse` ...
Is there another way? Is there a plan to accept z as a vector in the future?

messages.text:
Using linestyles is currently broken on CairoMakie because it interprets the dash-gap-patterns as multiples of linewidth.

I am happy to fix this in a PR. I just need to know if you want (W)GLMakie to interpret lengths as multiples of linewidth, or if CairoMakie should use a fixed scaling factor instead of linewidth. (I guess <@UK1BNFHFV> is the go-to person when it comes to aesthetics ;-))

see <https://github.com/JuliaPlots/Makie.jl/issues/807#issue-781251725>

messages.text:
```fig, ax, plt = lines(1:2, 2:3, linestyle="-....", linewidth=2)
lines!(1:2, 3:4, linestyle=(".", :dense), linewidth=2)
lines!(1:2, 4:5, linestyle=("-", :loose), linewidth=2)
lines!(1:2, 5:6, linestyle=(:dash, :dense), linewidth=2)
lines!(1:2, 6:7, linestyle=(:dash, 0.0), linewidth=2)
fig```

messages.text:
Hi there, is there an easy way to get the axis (in a gridlayout) which the mouse hovers over, from the mouse position. E.g. something like
```on(scene.events.mouseposition) do mpos
    ax = mpos2ax(mpos)
    # manipulate ax here
end```
I’m trying to implement a hovertool which shows some text when the mouse is pointing at a specific plot.

messages.text:
Is there a way to retrieve the object that a GridLayout entry was set to? I.e.:

```ax = layout[1, 1] = Axis(scene, title = "title")```
`ax == layout[1,1]` returns false which is a bit weird, but regardless if I no longer have `ax` it seems I should somehow be able to retrieve it from `layout[1,1]` , but how?
